> I do hope unmanned vehicles will come first in this new tech tree.

Why would Kerbals use machines to go into space for them, except once it's become routine, safe, and boring. You think Jeb wouldn't just sneak on board anyway, just for the thrill of it? Sure, we did unmanned missions first, but we're strangely risk-averse.

> Why would Kerbals use machines to go into space for them, except once it's become routine, safe, and boring. You think Jeb wouldn't just sneak on board anyway, just for the thrill of it? Sure, we did unmanned missions first, but we're strangely risk-averse.

Yeah I remember once planning to have each of the Big Three command a separate ship in a 3 ship fleet bound for Duna (some of them really space stations that I was planning to place over Duna) and I kept finding them stowing away on other missions when they were supposed to be back on Kerbin preparing for the Duna mission... WTH was Bob doing on the Minmus mining station????

> 
> <*citation needed*>

Measuring the number of people will be difficult. Any poll will have a selection bias, and the forum itself is a selection bias.

> 
> Measuring the number of people will be difficult. Any poll will have a selection bias, and the forum itself is a selection bias.

So it's crazy to make a statement like "most people don't play with mods" or "almost everyone plays with mods". All that's needed is evidence to back up such a statement. If no evidence can be produced, the statements are meaningless at best and downright wrong at worst.

> 
> So it's crazy to make a statement like "most people don't play with mods" or "almost everyone plays with mods". All that's needed is evidence to back up such a statement. If no evidence can be produced, the statements are meaningless at best and downright wrong at worst.

It's also crazy to ask for a citation of something that can't be cited.

I can't play mods. My hardware is what limits me. So, if, IF, (pay attention to the IF), if most people have hardware worse than mine (mine is fairly good, and still has trouble) then it's likely because of hardware. But that is a big IF...

Based on stats I \*have\* seen for other games, most people don't mod. They either don't play enough to exhaust the stock experience, didn't get into the game enough to ever bother, or don't even know that there is modding available.

Take Minecraft, for example. Back when I played, well over 90% of the public (or easy-to-get-on-private) servers out there were stock vanilla. Now there are other things to consider but the the simple fact that so many people were willing to play vanilla tells me it was not as rare a thing as a simple glance at the forum would lead you to believe.

The phrase "More people mod than don't" is more suspect to me than "More people play stock than don't," and would require more evidence to convince me of truth. I have no proof except (not 100% applicable) statistics, but that's good enough for me.

> 
> It's also crazy to ask for a citation of something that can't be cited.

That's the point; there's no solid evidence one way or the other. It's called sarcasm.

I would also tend to agree that out of the total number of KSP players, only a relatively small number play with mods. By the same logic, I would assume that most players have also never done a mission outside Kerbin's SOI. When the stats for a popular game like Mass Effect show that on average only about half the people even finish the game [[link](http://www.polygon.com/gaming/2012/8/14/3243277/bioware-completion-percentage-mass-effect-dragon-age)] (yes, I do realize that the player base is going to be very different, but still you get the idea) in a game that basically holds your hand and tells you where you're supposed to go next, I would guess that in a wide open game like KSP few people even know what mods are or what they're supposed to be doing and end up messing around in the VAB/SPH blowing stuff up for a few hours before maybe getting something into orbit (if they played the tutorials) or if they're really ambitious, getting to the Mun before getting bored and quitting KSP. If they accidentally click on the curse link on the main menu, they'll likely assume they clicked the wrong thing as opposed to finding the fascinating world of mods. If Squad wants mods to be more mainstream, they need to incorporate something like Steam Workshop.
